review.title: Understanding Concept Drift
review.abstract: Concept drift is a major issue that greatly affects the accuracy and reliability of many real-world applications of machine learning. We argue that to tackle concept drift it is important to develop the capacity to describe and analyze it. We propose tools for this purpose, arguing for the importance of quantitative descriptions of drift in marginal distributions. We present quantitative drift analysis techniques along with methods for communicating their results. We demonstrate their effectiveness by application to three real-world learning tasks.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: The world is dynamic, in constant flux. But machine learning usually creates static models from historical data. As the world changes, these models can become increasingly unreliable. There has been a very considerable effort to investigate methods for detecting concept drift (Kifer et al, 2004; Gama et al, 2004; Baena-Garcıa et al, 2006; Dries und RÃ ¼ ckert, 2009; Bifet et al, 2013; Qahtan et al, 2015). However, in applications where drift is ongoing, these techniques may be of limited use as they should always represent flag drift as the present. In such cases, instead of simply marking whether drift occurs or not, it may be more useful to generate a detailed description of the nature and shape of drift. sections.heading: 4 Measuring marginal drift magnitude
sections.text: The key to describing the drift in different attribute subranges is to measure the drift in the boundary distributions defined by different combinations of attributes. One problem that arises from this is how to estimate the required probability distributions from the available data. However, in order to manage the variance in the estimates, it is important to derive it from sufficiently large data samples (such as the distribution for a given hour, day, or week). However, this handy driver is not the only reason for considering the drift between extended time periods rather than the drift between instantaneous points in time. As we show in Section 6, looking at the drift between periods of different granularity can be extremely instructive.

sections.heading: 5 Methods for communicating drift maps
sections.text: Our primary technique measures boundary deviations between periods. Sometimes, it will be interesting to consider a single such comparison at a given time. At other times, it will be useful to think about how deviations unfold over a longer period of time, which can result in a very large number of individual deviations. At this point, we present methods for communicating this large amount of information.For deviations between two periods, the key information we want to convey is the relative extent of the deviation in any combination of attributes. We find that thermal imaging maps are a highly effective means of doing this, clearly highlighting the interactions between the variables. We provide examples in Figures 11 to 14. We use line diagrams to communicate the evolution of the deviation over longer periods of time.
